The series premiere of ''Bones'' attracted an average of 10.8 million viewers with 6.7% household share and 11% household rating. ''Bones'' finished first among the 18-to-49-year-old [[demographic]] and in total viewers in its Tuesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm [[North American Eastern Standard Time|ET]] timeslot.<ref>{{cite web |last=Berman |first=Marc |url=http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001177629 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114125403/http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001177629 |archivedate=November 14, 2007 |title=National Ratings in Primetime – Week of September 12, 2005 |publisher=The Programming Insider |date=September 21, 2005 |accessdate=May 20, 2007}}</ref> ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' described the show as "the best drama of the new network season" and a "sexed-up variation of all the CSIs".<ref>{{cite news |last=Leonard |first=John |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/tv/reviews/15227 |title=Bodies in Motion |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=December 12, 2005 |accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref> Regarding the show's procedural structure, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' notes that ''Bones'' has a "pretty standard ''[[Crossing Jordan]]''/[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|''CSI'']]-style framework" but holds up because of the chemistry between the two lead characters; "that old [[Sam-and-Diane]], [[Moonlighting (TV series)|Maddie-and-David]], [[The X-Files|Mulder-and-Scully]] opposites-attract stuff never feels standard when it's done right."<ref>{{cite news|last=Flynn|first=Gillian|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1102765,00.html|title=Bones Review|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=September 9, 2005|accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref>
Following the broadcast of the series' third episode, Fox ordered a full season of ''Bones''.<ref>{{cite press |publisher=Fox Broadcasting Company |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2005/10/12/fox-orders-full-seasons-of-the-hit-series-bones-and-the-war-at-home--19493/20051012fox02 |title=FOX orders full seasons of the hit series "Bones" and "The War at Home" |date=October 12, 2005 |accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref> The network renewed it for a second season after a strong performance in ratings in the timeslot following ''[[American Idol]]'' and on its own without the American Idol's lead-in audience.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sullivan |first=Brian Ford |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=7119 |title=FOX to keep 'Bones', The WB's 'What I Like About You' to end |publisher=The Futon Critic |date=March 24, 2006 |accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref> Overall, the first season of ''Bones'' ranked 60th in viewership among prime-time shows and 53rd among the 18 to 49 year old demographic, with a seasonal average of 8.9 million viewers.<ref name="Season1Ratings" />
The second-season premiere attracted 8.61 million viewers in its Wednesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm timeslot, finishing second among the 18 to 49 years old demographic and first in total viewership with 6.7% household rating and 11% household share.<ref>{{cite web|last=Berman|first=Marc|url=http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003118162|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114125413/http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003118162 |archivedate=November 14, 2007 |title=Primetime Wednesday Ratings|publisher=The Programming Insider|date=September 7, 2006|accessdate=May 20, 2007}}</ref> As a lead-in for ''American Idol'', the second-season finale of ''Bones'' obtained 10.88 million viewers with 3.5% household rating and 11% household share. It tied first in viewership among the 18 to 49 years old demographic with ''[[The Price Is Right Million Dollar Spectacular]]'' on ''[[CBS]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kissell|first=Rick|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117965147|title='Idol' cleans up, viewers find 'Lost'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=May 17, 2007|accessdate=May 20, 2007}}</ref> In the 2006–07 television season, ''Bones'' improved its ranking to 50th place in viewership among prime-time shows with 9.4 million viewers and was ranked 51st among the 18 to 49 year old demographic. The show improved its ranking during its third season, placing 51st overall. However, its overall viewership was down from the previous season, averaging 8.9 million, the same as in the first season. Viewership began to steadily increase with its fourth season.
The ninth-season premiere attracted 7.8 million viewers and a 2.3 rating in the key 18–49 demographic during its Monday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm timeslot. Its final Monday airing resulted in a 2.0 rating and 7.36 million viewers. ''Bones'' was subsequently moved to Fridays at 8:00{{nbsp}}pm November 15, 2013, where ratings dropped 40 percent to a 1.2 and 5.85 million viewers in its initial airing in that timeslot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/11/16/tv-ratings-friday-bones-falls-raising-hope-returns-low-grimm-hawaii-five-0-the-carrie-diaries-up-dracula-flat|title=TV Ratings Friday: 'Bones' Falls in New Timeslot, 'Raising Hope' Returns Low, 'Grimm', 'Hawaii Five-0' & 'The Carrie Diaries' Up, 'Dracula' Flat|publisher=TV by the Numbers|first=Sara|last=Bibel|date=November 16, 2013|accessdate=November 18, 2013}}</ref>
===Broadcast history=== ''Bones'' premiered September 13, 2005, on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] and was broadcast weekly in the Tuesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|ET]] timeslot before it moved to the Wednesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET timeslot in 2006. The first season finished May 17, 2006, with a total of 22 episodes.
The second season premiered on the Fox network August 30, 2006, and retained its Wednesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET timeslot. The second-season finale aired May 16, 2007, ending its second season with 21 episodes. One episode, "Player Under Pressure", was left unaired, which was originally scheduled to be broadcast as the second season's 19th episode but was pulled by the Fox network in the United States after the [[Virginia Tech massacre]]. The plot involved the discovery of the human remains of a college athlete<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-foxpullsbonesepisode,0,4937407.story|title=Fox Pulls 'Bones' Episode After Tragedy|publisher=Zap2it|date=April 17, 2007|accessdate=February 3, 2013}}</ref> and eventually aired April 21, 2008, as a part of the third season.
The third season premiered September 25, 2007, in its original premiere timeslot, Tuesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET. The show went on hiatus on November 27, 2007, because of the [[2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike]] and returned on April 14, 2008, in the Monday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET timeslot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20080205fox01|title=Episode "House's" record-setting post-super bowl episode "frozen" to encore Friday, February 15|publisher=The Futon Critic|date=February 5, 2008|accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref> The shortened third season finished May 19, 2008, with a total of 15 episodes.
The fourth season premiered September 3, 2008, on the Fox network in the Wednesday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET timeslot with a two-hour episode that was filmed on location in [[London]] and [[Oxford]], [[England]].<ref name="TheFutonCritic">{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20080605fox01|title=FOX Announces Fall Premiere Dates for the 2008–2009 Season|accessdate=June 7, 2008|date=June 5, 2008|publisher=The Futon Critic}}</ref> Originally scheduled to return from hiatus January 15, 2009, ''Bones'' instead resumed one week later because of preemption by [[George W. Bush|President Bush]]'s farewell address. As a result, two new episodes, "Double Trouble in the Panhandle" and "Fire in the Ice", were aired back-to-back January 22, 2009, airing in a new timeslot, Thursday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET. The fourth-season finale aired May 14, 2009 with a total of 26 episodes.
The fifth season premiered September 17, 2009, on the Fox network and retained its Thursday 8:00{{nbsp}}pm ET timeslot. It consisted of 22 episodes and ended May 20, 2010.
Off-network syndication of ''Bones'' began the week of January 28, 2008, on [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/bones/tnt-to-air-bones-repeats-16049.aspx|title=TNT to Air 'Bones' Repeats|publisher=BuddyTV|first=Lisa|last=Claustro|date=January 25, 2008|accessdate=December 20, 2012}}</ref>
March 29, 2012, announcing the renewal for an eighth season, [[Kevin Reilly (executive)|Kevin Reilly]], Fox's Chairman of Entertainment, said, "Over the past seven seasons, Hart Hanson, Stephen Nathan and the incredible ''Bones'' cast and crew have redefined the traditional crime procedural with an irreverent and adventurous sensibility, and I'm really happy to have this distinctive fan-favorite on our schedule for another season."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Reilly|first=Kevin|title=They Said It!|journal=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|location= New York|publisher=NewBay Media|volume=142|issue=14|date=April 2, 2012|page=4}}</ref>
===Online distribution=== Fox has released free episodes of ''Bones'' and several other primetime series online for viewing on [[Netflix]], [[Hulu]], and its [[MySpace]] website, which is owned by the same parent company, [[News Corporation]] (now [[21st Century Fox]]), that owns Fox. This began October 3, 2006, but access is restricted to United States residents only.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/10/03/free-episodes-available-for-download|title=Free Episodes Available For Download|publisher=IGN|date=October 3, 2006|accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref> ''Bones'' was available on their official website via Fox On Demand. In Canada, recent episodes were made available on the [[Global TV]] website. In the U.S. and Canada, the series has been available on [[Netflix]]. All twelve seasons are also available on [[Amazon Prime]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/video/detail/B00N99SCSG/|title=Bones|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=November 10, 2018}}</ref>
==Spin-off series== {{Main|The Finder (U.S. TV series)}}
In October 2010, it was revealed that Fox was developing a potential spin-off series that would be built around a new recurring character that would be introduced in the sixth season. The potential spin-off series would also be created by ''Bones'' creator/executive producer [[Hart Hanson]], and be based on ''The Locator'' series of two books written by Richard Greener. The character of Walter is described as an eccentric but amusing recluse in high demand for his ability to find anything. He is skeptical of everything—he suffered brain damage while overseas, which explains his constant paranoia and his being notorious for asking offensive, seemingly irrelevant questions to get to the truth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/10/foxs-dramedy-bones-plots-spinoff-series|title=Fox's Dramedy 'Bones' Plots Spinoff Series|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|publisher=Deadline|date=October 21, 2010|accessdate=October 22, 2010}}</ref> Production on the episode was scheduled to begin in December 2010, but was delayed to early 2011 due to creative differences.
Creator Hart Hanson posted on [[Twitter]] (humorously) regarding the notes he got from the network, "I received studio notes on the ''Bones'' spin-off idea. They want it to be better. Unreasonable taskmasters. Impossible dreamers. Neo-platonists."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news-briefs.ew.com/2010/11/09/bones-spin-off-episode-delayed|title='Bones' spin-off episode delayed|last=Bierly|first=Mandi|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=November 9, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213090803/http://news-briefs.ew.com/2010/11/09/bones-spin-off-episode-delayed/|archivedate=December 13, 2010}}</ref> During Fox's TCA press tour, executive producer Stephen Nathan revealed production on the episode featuring The Finder began in February 2011, with the episode airing in April.
In the episode, Booth and Brennan travel to [[Key West, Florida]], where the spin-off is said to take place. Nathan went on to say regarding the casting of character, <blockquote>"You want to find people you want to see every single week do one unique character. That's why when you have [[Hugh Laurie]], who is essentially playing a very unlikable character, you love to see him. And that is a rare, rare quality to find. And the finder won't be an unlikable character, but because it is a unique character, it's difficult to find just the right person."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/01/13/bones-booth-brennan-elevator|title='Bones': Details on the Booth-and-Brennan-are-stuck-in-an-elevator Episode|last=Bierly|first=Mandi|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=January 13, 2011|accessdate=January 15, 2011}}</ref></blockquote> [[Geoff Stults]] was cast as the lead character with [[Michael Clarke Duncan]] and [[Saffron Burrows]] cast as the other two lead characters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/01/bones-spinoff-casts-geoff-stults-as-locator|title=''Bones'' Spin-off Finds Its 'Locator', Casts Geoff Stults As Lead|last=Webb Mitovich|first=Matt| publisher=TVLine|date=January 28, 2011|accessdate=January 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/01/exclusive-foxs-high-profile-bones-spinoff-lands-michael-clarke-duncan|title=Fox's High-Profile 'Bones' Spinoff Lands Michael Clarke Duncan|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|publisher=TVLine|date=January 19, 2011|accessdate=January 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/02/scoop-bones-spinoff-lands-saffron-burrows|title=Scoop: 'Bones' Spinoff Lands Saffron Burrows|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|publisher=TVLine|date=February 14, 2011|accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref> The three characters were introduced in [[Bones (season 6)#ep125|episode 19 of the sixth season]].
''The Finder'' was picked up for the 2011–12 season May 10, 2011, with an order of 13 episodes.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hibberd |first=James |title=Fox picks up 'Bones' spin-off 'The Finder,' J.J. Abrams 'Alcatraz' to series |url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/05/10/fox-bones-spin-off-the-finder |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=May 10, 2011 |accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> The series was canceled May 9, 2012, and aired its final episode two days later.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rose|first=Lacey|title=Fox Renews 'Touch'; Cancels 'Alcatraz,' 'The Finder'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/fox-renewals-cancellations-322656|accessdate=May 9, 2012|newspaper=Hollywood Reporter|date=May 9, 2012}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical response=== Reviews for the pilot episode were mixed, and it holds a [[Metacritic]] score of 55 out of 100, based on 29 critical reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bones/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Bones Season 1|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=July 13, 2012}}</ref> Subsequent episodes have received generally positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bones/season-4/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Bones Season 4|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=July 13, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bones/season-6/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Bones Season 6|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=July 13, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bones/season-7/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Bones Season 7|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=July 13, 2012}}</ref>
''[[USA Today]]'' comments that, compared to other crime shows, the show "is built on a more traditional and solid foundation: the strength of its characters", and "what sets Tuesday's ''Bones'' premiere apart from the procedural pack are stars Emily Deschanel and David Boreanaz, as the season's most appealing new crime fighters."<ref>{{cite news|last=Bianco|first=Robert|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/reviews/2005-09-12-bones_x.htm|title=The stars flesh out 'Bones'|work=[[USA Today]]|date=September 12, 2005|accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref> On the other hand, ''Media Life Magazine'' said that while ''Bones'' has "an amazingly clever notion, brilliant even", its "execution doesn't match the conception" and, based on its first episode, the show "fails to evolve into a gripping series. In fact, it quickly becomes so derivative of so much else on television — especially, strangely, ''[[The X-Files|X-Files]]'' — that one might even call it bone-headed."<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen |first=Steven |url=http://www.medialifemagazine.com/news2005/sep05/sept12/2_tues/news4tuesday.html |title='Bones', from the heap of tired ideas |work=Media Life Magazine |date=September 13, 2005 |accessdate=June 27, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930163624/http://www.medialifemagazine.com/News2005/sep05/sept12/2_tues/news4tuesday.html |archivedate=September 30, 2007 }}</ref>
===Accolades=== ''Bones'' has received two [[Emmy]] nominations, for Outstanding Art Direction for a Single Camera Series for "The Hero in the Hold" at the [[61st Primetime Emmy Awards]] and for Outstanding Special Visual Effects in a Supporting Role for "The Twist in the Twister" at the [[64th Primetime Emmy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.emmys.com/shows/bones |title=Bones |website=Emmys.com |accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref>
[[Emily Deschanel]] was nominated for a 2006 [[Satellite Award]] for [[Satellite Award for Best Actress – Television Series Drama|Best Actress – Television Series Drama]].
The series has also won two [[Genesis Awards]] for the episodes "The Woman in Limbo" and "The Tough Man in the Tender Chicken" for raising awareness on the issues of [[pig slaughter]]ing and industrial chicken farms, while the episode "The Finger in the Nest" received a nomination.
''Bones'' was nominated for two awards at the [[37th People's Choice Awards]], for Favorite TV Crime Drama and Emily Deschanel for Favorite TV Crime Fighter.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp?year=2011 |title=People's Choice Awards 2011 Nominees |publisher=PeoplesChoice.com |accessdate=November 18, 2010}}</ref> The series received three nominations at the [[38th People's Choice Awards]], for Favorite TV Crime Drama, David Boreanaz for Favorite TV Drama Actor and Emily Deschanel for Favorite TV Drama Actress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp?year=2012|title=People's Choice Awards 2012 Nominees|publisher=PeoplesChoice.com|accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> The series received two nominations at the [[42nd People's Choice Awards]], for Favorite TV Crime Drama and Emily Deschanel for Favorite TV Crime Drama Actress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp?year=2016|title=People's Choice Awards 2016 Nominees|publisher=PeoplesChoice.com|accessdate=November 9, 2015}}</ref>
''Bones'' was nominated for a 2014 Prism Award for Best Drama Episode – Substance Abuse for the episode "The Friend in Need" and [[John Francis Daley]] for Best Performance in a Drama Series Episode.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prism.eiconline.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/14-PRISM-Nomination-Release_Final06Mar141.pdf|title=18th PRISM Awards|publisher=PRISM Awards|format=PDF|date=March 6, 2014|accessdate=April 7, 2014}}</ref>
==Other media== Aside from the television broadcast of ''Bones'', its characters and concepts have also been produced in print, on the Internet and in short videos for mobile phones. Currently, there are two print books related to the series, one a novel and the other an official guide.
* ''Buried Deep'' (also released as "Bones Buried Deep"; {{ISBN|978-1-4165-2461-8}}), written by [[Max Allan Collins]], was published by Pocket Star February 28, 2006. The book is based on the characters in the television series rather than the characters created by [[Kathy Reichs]], who had inspired the concept of ''Bones''. Its plot focuses on Dr. Temperance Brennan and Special Agent Seeley Booth's investigation into the skeletal remains left on the steps of a federal building and its connection with a Chicago mob family. Angela, Hodgins and Zack only appear on the end of telephone conversations with Brennan. * ''Bones: The Official Companion'' ({{ISBN|978-1-84576-539-2}}) is written by Paul Ruditis and published by Titan Books, released October 16, 2007. The book includes cast and crew interviews, episode guides and a background detail on real-life forensics.<ref>{{ASIN|1845765397|title=Bones: The Official Companion}}</ref>
Fox initially made extensive use of the internet to promote ''Bones''. Prior to the broadcast of the second-season episode "The Glowing Bones in the Old Stone House", profiles of the characters involved in the episode were put up on their own [[MySpace]] web page. The blog entries of the characters were created to give insight into the potential suspects to be featured in the episode. In the episode, Brennan and her team uses clues from these web pages, which the viewers can also access.<ref>{{cite web|last=Krause|first=Staci|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/04/04/bones-crosses-over-into-life|title=Bones Crosses Over Into Life|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=April 4, 2007|accessdate=June 27, 2007}}</ref>
A spin-off series consisting of 26 two-minute episodes, called ''Bones: Skeleton Crew'', was produced by Fox and launched through a partnership with [[Sprint Nextel]] in conjunction with [[MasterCard]]'s sponsorship. It was released to Sprint TV subscribers in November 2006 and released on the official website of ''Bones'' on December 4, 2006. The episodes do not feature the show's main cast; its plot revolves around three Jeffersonian Institute lab technicians who use their skills to solve a mystery.<ref>{{cite web|last=Scott|first=Andrew|url=http://chiefmarketer.com/entertainmentmarketing/mc_mobisodes_111606|title=MasterCard Places Brand in Fox Mobisodes|publisher=Chief Marketer|date=November 16, 2006|accessdate=June 27, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120712200244/http://chiefmarketer.com/entertainmentmarketing/mc_mobisodes_111606|archivedate=July 12, 2012}}</ref>
Bonus content was posted by Fox on ''Bones''{{'}} official site during the third season, which include short videos featuring Booth and Brennan waiting to see Dr. Sweets for couple's therapy.
==Home media== The first three seasons, the ninth, tenth, eleventh and twelfth season were released on DVD format only, while seasons four through eight were also released on [[Blu-ray Disc]] format.

{{cleanup-reorganize|date=March 2015}} [[File:Intel D87C51-3183.jpg|thumb|Intel D87C51. Fabricated on Intel's CHMOS III-E technology. A member of the [[Intel MCS-51|MCS-51]] controller family]] '''CHMOS''' refers to one of a series of Intel [[CMOS]] processes developed from their [[Depletion-load NMOS logic#The HMOS processes|HMOS]] process. (H stands for high-density).
CHMOS was used in the Intel [[80C51BH]], a new version of their standard [[MCS-51]] microcontroller.<ref>[http://www.computinghistory.org.uk/det/3486/intel-chmos-microcontroller-design-kit/ Intel CHMOS Microcontroller Design Kit]</ref> The chip was also used in later versions of [[Intel 8086]], and the [[80C88]], which were fully static version of the [[Intel 8088]]. The [[Intel 80386]] was made in 1.5 µm CHMOS III, and later in 1.0 µm CHMOS IV.
CHMOS III used 1.5 micron [[Photolithography|lithography]], p-well processing, and two layers of metal.<ref>[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?arnumber=1484411 A double layer metal CHMOS III technology]</ref>
CHMOS IV (H stands for High Speed) used 1.0 µm lithography. Many versions of the [[Intel 80486]] were made in 1.0 µm CHMOS IV.
CHMOS V used 0.8 µm lithography and 3 metal layers, and was used in later versions of the 80386 and 80486 and [[Intel i860]].
==See also== * [[Depletion-load NMOS logic#Further development]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{advert|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox company | logo = | name = CISC Semiconductor GmbH | type = Private | foundation = 1999 | location = [[Klagenfurt]], [[Austria]] | key_people = Dr. Markus Pistauer, CEO and DI [[Josef Preishuber-Pflügl]], CTO | homepage = {{URL|www.cisc.at}} | industry = [[Electronics]] | products = [[Semiconductors]], [[Automotive]], [[RFID]] }}
'''CISC Semiconductor GmbH''' defines itself as “''design and consulting service company for industries developing embedded microelectronic systems with extremely short Time-To-Market cycles.''” The company started in 1999, working on solutions for the [[semiconductor industry]], but soon expanded its field towards the [[automotive|automotive branch]] and further extended business towards the [[radio frequency identification|radio frequency technology]] ([[RFID]]) sector in 2003. Since then, CISC gained significant experience and expertise in [[RFID]], developing an own business segment and highly sensitive measurement equipment to test and verify RFID systems for different industries. Representatives of CISC Semiconductor are actively working on and contributing to worldwide [[standardization]] of future technologies like [[RFID]], in different standardization organizations. This effort brings CISC into the position of being a leader in research and development, and thus being able to be “''one step ahead of innovation''”. As of 2011 CISC Semiconductor is in a globally leading standardization position for [[RFID testing]] by providing the convener of ISO/IEC JTC1 WG4/SG6<ref>[https://www.cisc.at/services/standardization.html ''International Standardization participation of CISC'']. CISC Semiconductor. Retrieved 13 June 2012.</ref> on “RFID performance and conformance test methods“, as well as [[GS1]] [[EPCglobal]] co-chairs for performance and conformance tests.
Their main office is at the [[Lakeside Science & Technology Park]] in [[Klagenfurt]], Austria near the [[University of Klagenfurt]]. A branch office is located in [[Graz]], Austria, enabling a close cooperation with the [[Graz University of Technology]].
== History ==
*CISC Semiconductor Design+Consulting GmbH was founded in 1999 as an [[Research and Development|R&D]] focused and 100% privately owned business by CEO [[Markus Pistauer|Dr. Markus Pistauer]] in [[Klagenfurt|Klagenfurt, Austria]]. *Between 2000 and 2002 CISC was part of two international R&D <s: “High Quality Design in Deep Submicron Technology” and “Technology Driven Design and Test”.<ref>[http://www.catrene.org/web/downloads/profiles_medea/T101_profile.pdf ''TechnoDat Project Profile'']. CARTENE. Retrieved 9 September 2011.</ref> *In 2002 CISC opened an R&D center in [[Graz|Graz, Austria]] with the purpose of enabling a closer cooperation with the Institute for Technical Informatics at [[Graz University of Technology]]. *In 2003 CISC Semiconductor expanded its business towards [[radio-frequency identification|radio frequency identification (RFID)]] and radio frequency (RF) communication, laying the foundation for its current activity in various [[standardization]] processes. *Getting further into [[radio-frequency identification|RFID technology]], CISC became a member of [[EPCglobal]]™ and started participating in [[RFID]] [[standardization]] work for the first time in 2004. *In 2004 CISC launched its product SyAD<sup>®</sup> (System Architect Designer) and won an Austrian Innovation and Research Prize Award ([[Carinthia (state)|Province Carinthia]]).<ref>[https://www.cisc.at/company/about/awards/innovation-prize-2004.html ''Innovationspreis des Landes Kärnten''] CISC Semiconductor. Retrieved 13 June 2012.</ref> *Since 2004 CISC is organized in three business units: Automotive (AT), RFID+RFComm (RF) and Tools+Methodology (TM). *CISC joined two European R&D projects: “Robust Design for Efficient Use of Nanometer Technologies” (ROBIN)<ref>[https://www.cisc.at/company/partner-rd/international-projects/recent.html?#c78 ''Information about the ROBIN project''] CISC Semiconductor. Retrieved 13 June 2012</ref> and “Wireless Technologies for small area Networks with Embedded Security and Safety” (Witness),<ref>[https://www.cisc.at/company/partner-rd/international-projects/recent.html?#c77 ''Information about the Witness research project''.] CISC Semiconductor. Retrieved 13 June 2012.</ref> starting in 2004. *In 2006 CISC won a special economy prize<ref>[https://www.cisc.at/company/about/awards/economy-prize-2006.html''Wirtschaftspreis 2006''] CISC Semiconductor. Retrieved 13 June 2012.</ref> on high innovative products (by Privatstiftung Kärntner Sparkasse, Austria) for its RFID Application and System Design Toolset (CISC RFID ASD Kit+Library), which was brought to the market in the same year, as well as another RF product: The CISC RFID Field Recorder<sup>®</sup>. *From 2006 on CISC started providing expert training on RFID via the European EPC Competence Center. *In the year 2007 CISC launched products in all its three business units: AT (Automotive Bus System Lib and Automotive Core Lib), RF (Tag Emulator<sup>®</sup> and MeETS), as well as TM (SyAD<sup>®</sup> V2.0). *Furthermore, in 2007 CISC and its products were present at four continents: Europe, Asia, Africa and America, further extending the company’s export efforts. * In 2007 CISC joined the Open SystemC initiative and became certified Alliance Partner of [[National Instruments]]. *In January 2007 CISC opened its R&D branch office in [[Graz]], [[Austria]]. *Two new research projects were started in 2008: “SR2 – Short Range Radio” and “TEODACS – Test, Evaluation and Optimization of Dependable Automotive Communication Systems” at the Virtual Vehicle Competence Center.<ref>[http://vif.tugraz.at/nc/en/research/vehicle-ee-and-software/projects/teodacs/ ''TEODACS Project Description and Overview''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402114254/http://vif.tugraz.at/nc/en/research/vehicle-ee-and-software/projects/teodacs/# |date=2012-04-02 }}.Kompetenzzentrum ''Das virtuelle Fahrzeug'' Forschungsgesellschaft GmbH. Retrieved 13 September 2011</ref> Another one followed in 2009: “e3car” via the [[ENIAC JTI|ENIAC]] [[Joint Technology Initiative|Joint Undertaking]],<ref>[http://www.eniac.eu/web/downloads/projectprofiles/call1_eniac_e3car.pdf ''e3car Project Profile'']. ENIAC Joint Undertaking. Retrieved 13 September 2011.</ref> which was meant to push the development of hybrid and electrical vehicles. *In 2010 CISC pushed product development in the business units RF and TM, improving MeETS to achieve measurement sensitivities of [[Ultra high frequency|UHF RFID]] tag performance measurements beyond [[dBm|-100dBm]]<ref>Derbek/Preishuber-Pfluegl/Pistauer/Holtstiege (2010): Method of Receiver Sensitivity Improvement for RFID Measurement and Test Instruments. Cartagena: IEEE, S. 39-42.</ref> and releasing SyAD<sup>®</sup>’s 3rd generation – SyAD<sup>®</sup> 2010. *From 2010 on CISC Semiconductor is official industry partner of the [[Munich University of Technology]] joining their RFID AZM (RFID User Center Munich). *The international research project: “Process Oriented Electronic Control Units for Electric Vehicles Developed on a Multi-System Real-Time Embedded Platform” (POLLUX)<ref>[http://www.artemis-pollux.eu/project.htm ''POLLUX Project Page''.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402114254/http://www.artemis-pollux.eu/project.htm# |date=2012-04-02 }} ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. Retrieved 13 September 2011.</ref> under the umbrella of ARTEMIS [[Joint Technology Initiative|Joint Undertaking]]<ref>[http://www.artemis-ju.eu/ ''ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. ''] Retrieved 13 September 2011.</ref> started in 2010. *In 2011 the company’s name was changed to CISC Semiconductor GmbH, eliminating the phrase “Design+Consulting” to better fit the current field of business. *In Spring 2012 CISC Semiconductor decided to adapt and change its logo to visualize the development that the company has gone through since its foundation in 1999. *The Company's new product - RFID Xplorer - was successfully launched in April and presented at the Euro ID trade fair in Berlin.
== Main Markets == CISC Semiconductor’s main markets are situated in the [[semiconductor industry|Semiconductor]], [[Automotive]] and [[RFID|RFID industry]]. Tools and techniques are designed for simulation based system development of [[Embedded systems|embedded microelectronic systems]], including RFID systems. The most important markets include:
*[[Electronic design automation|EDA (Electronic Design Automation)]] – e.g. design and simulation frameworks *[[RFID|RFID (Radiofrequency Identification)]] – e.g. measurement and test equipment for tags, readers and systems
== Competences == The company’s core competences are ranging from [[system design]], [[System modeling|modeling]] and [[System Simulation|simulation]] to verification and optimization of heterogeneous, embedded, microelectronic systems, with a particular focus on [[Automotive]] and [[Radio-frequency identification|RFID]] systems. CISC’s versatile competences are reflected in their business units:
=== Automotive === In terms of [[Automotive]], CISC offers various tools and services related to [[Microelectronic Engineering|microelectronic engineering]] work, assisting in development work by providing know-how and tools to support design engineers.
=== RFID+RFComm === In [[Radio-frequency identification|RFID and RF communication]] CISC’s competences are covering experience in RFID product development, simulation tool development and RFID measurement systems as well as experience in evaluation, modelling, simulation and testing of RFID products and systems. Furthermore, CISC is experienced with RFID trainings and consulting and plays a leading role in [[Standardization|RFID standardization]] ([[International Organization for Standardization|ISO/IEC]], [[EPCglobal]] and [[European Telecommunications Standards Institute|ETSI]]).
=== Tools+Methodology === Within the business unit Tools+Methodology, CISC works on [[system design]], [[System modeling|modeling]], [[System Simulation|simulation]], verification and optimization of heterogeneous embedded microelectronic systems, as well as software engineering e.g. for the [[Electronic design automation|EDA industry]].
== Standardization == CISC’s history in [[standardization]] started in 2003 with the expansion of its business towards the [[wireless communication|wireless communication technology]] [[Radio-frequency identification|RFID (radiofrequency identification)]]. With the development of a new business segment and several RFID measurement products, CISC representatives – especially [[Josef Preishuber-Pflügl]] – started to play an active role in international standardization. Since then, CISC has been actively participating in international RFID standardization processes ([[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]], [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]], [[European Telecommunications Standards Institute|ETSI]], [[Austrian Standards Institute|ASI/ÖNORM]]) and is currently active member of [[EPCglobal]] and the [[Low Power Radio Association|LPRA (Low Power Radio Association)]]. CISC’s input on standards and technology development ensures to keep technology in line by continuous development and change of regulatory constraints.
CISC is active member of several different standardization working groups, currently CISC provides the convener of ISO/IEC JTC1 SC31 WG4/SG6<ref>[http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_technical_committee.html?commid=45332 ''ISO/IEC technical committee on automatic identification and data capture techniques''.] Retrieved 9 September 2011.</ref> responsible for performance and conformance measurements for RFID for item management, the project editor for [[ISO/IEC 18000|ISO/IEC 18000-6]] “UHF RFID air interface”,<ref>[http://www.marktplatz-rfid-im-blick.de/201105303080/cisc-semiconductor-ueber-die-vereinheitlichung-der-uhf-rfid-baender.html ''Über die Vereinheitlichung der UHF-RFID Bänder.''] Article on Standardization Development of the ISo/IEC 18000-6 UHF RFID Air Interface. RFID-im-Blick. Retrieved 9 September 2011.</ref> ISO/IEC 29167 “RFID security”,<ref>[http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=55847 ''Standard ISO/IEC 29167 on Air Interface for security services and file management for RFID architecture.''] Retrieved 9 September 2011.</ref> the convener of the Austrian AG 001.31, the national mirror committee of ISO/IEC JTC1 SC31, as well as the vice-chairmen to ETSI ERM TG34<ref>[http://portal.etsi.org/erm/ERMtg34_ToR.asp ''ETSI ERM Task Group 34 on Radio Frequency Identification Devices (RFID).''] Retrieved 9 September 2011.</ref> responsible for RFID regulatory.
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

''See also [[ISFET]]''
A '''ChemFET''' is a '''chemically-sensitive field-effect transistor''', that is a [[field-effect transistor]] used as a [[sensor]] for measuring chemical concentrations in solution.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reinhoudt|first=David N.|date=|title=Application of supramolecular chemistry in the development of ion-selective CHEMFETs|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/092540059280052Y|journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical|volume=6|issue=1-3|pages=179|doi=10.1016/0925-4005(92)80052-y|via=}}</ref> When the target analyte concentration changes, the current through the [[transistor]] will change accordingly.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lugtenberg|first=Ronny J. W.|last2=Antonisse|first2=Martijn M. G.|last3=Egberink|first3=Richard J. M.|last4=Engbersen|first4=Johan F. J.|last5=Reinhoudt|first5=David N.|date=1996-01-01|title=Polysiloxane based CHEMFETs for the detection of heavy metal ions|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=p29960001937|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Perkin Transactions 2|language=en|volume=0|issue=9|doi=10.1039/p29960001937|issn=1364-5471}}</ref> Here, the analyte solution separates the source and gate electrodes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Janata|first=Jiri|date=2004-11-01|title=Thirty Years of CHEMFETs – A Personal View|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elan.200403070/abstract|journal=Electroanalysis|language=en|volume=16|issue=22|pages=1831|doi=10.1002/elan.200403070|issn=1521-4109|via=}}</ref> A concentration gradient between the solution and the gate electrode arises due to a semi-permeable membrane on the FET surface containing receptor moieties that preferentially bind the target analyte.<ref name=":0" /> This concentration gradient of charged analyte ions creates a chemical potential between the source and gate, which is in turn measured by the FET.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Bergveld|first=P.|date=|title=Thirty years of ISFETOLOGY|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0925400502003015|journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical|volume=88|issue=1|pages=1|doi=10.1016/s0925-4005(02)00301-5|via=}}</ref>
== Construction == [[File:ChemFET.png|thumb|The schematic view of a ChemFET. Source, drain, and gate are the three electrodes used in a FET system. The electron flow takes place in a channel between the drain and source. The gate potential controls the current between the source and drain electrodes.]] A ChemFET’s source and drain are constructed as for an [[ISFET]], with the gate electrode separated from the source electrode by a solution.<ref name=":1" /> The gate electrode’s interface with the solution is a semi-permeable membrane containing the receptors, and a gap to allow the substance under test to come in contact with the sensitive receptor moieties.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Antonisse|first=Martijn M. G.|last2=Reinhoudt|first2=David N.|date=1999-10-01|title=Potentiometric Anion Selective Sensors|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1521-4109(199910)11:143.0.CO;2-I/abstract|journal=Electroanalysis|language=en|volume=11|issue=14|pages=1035|doi=10.1002/(sici)1521-4109(199910)11:14%3C1035::aid-elan1035%3E3.0.co;2-i|issn=1521-4109|via=}}</ref> A ChemFET’s [[threshold voltage]] depends on the concentration gradient between the analyte in solution and the analyte in contact with its receptor-embedded semi-permeable barrier.<ref name=":2" />
Often, [[ionophore]]s are used to facilitate analyte ion mobility through the substrate to the receptor.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wróblewski|first=Wojciech|last2=Wojciechowski|first2=Kamil|last3=Dybko|first3=Artur|last4=Brzózka|first4=Zbigniew|last5=Egberink|first5=Richard J.M|last6=Snellink-Ruël|first6=Bianca H.M|last7=Reinhoudt|first7=David N|title=Durability of phosphate-selective CHEMFETs|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0925400501008322|journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical|volume=78|issue=1-3|pages=315–319|doi=10.1016/s0925-4005(01)00832-2}}</ref> For example when targeting anions, [[Quaternary ammonium cation|quaternary ammonium salts]] (such as [[tetraoctylammonium bromide]]) are used to provide cationic nature to the membrane, facilitating anion mobility through the substrate to the receptor moieties.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Antonisse|first=Martijn M. G.|last2=Snellink-Ruël|first2=Bianca H. M.|last3=Engbersen|first3=Johan F. J.|last4=Reinhoudt|first4=David N.|date=1998-01-01|title=Chemically modified field effect transistors with nitrite or fluoride selectivity|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=a709076e|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Perkin Transactions 2|language=en|volume=0|issue=4|pages=775|doi=10.1039/a709076e|issn=1364-5471|via=}}</ref>
== Applications == ChemFETs can be utilized in either liquid or gas phase to detect target analyte, requiring reversible binding of analyte with a receptor located in the gate electrode membrane.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Han|first=Jin-Woo|last2=Rim|first2=Taiuk|last3=Baek|first3=Chang-Ki|last4=Meyyappan|first4=M.|date=2015-09-30|title=Chemical Gated Field Effect Transistor by Hybrid Integration of One-Dimensional Silicon Nanowire and Two-Dimensional Tin Oxide Thin Film for Low Power Gas Sensor|url=https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.5b05479|journal=ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces|volume=7|issue=38|pages=21263|doi=10.1021/acsami.5b05479|issn=1944-8244|via=}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> There is a wide range of applications of ChemFETs, including most notably anion or cation selective sensing.<ref name=":2" /> More work has been done with cation-sensing ChemFETs than anion-sensing ChemFETs.<ref name=":2" /> Anion-sensing is more complicated than cation-sensing in ChemFETs due to many factors, including the size, shape, geometry, polarity, and pH of the species of interest.<ref name=":2" />
== Practical Limitations == The body of a ChemFET is generally found to be robust.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jimenez-Jorquera|first=Cecilia|last2=Orozco|first2=Jahir|last3=Baldi|first3=Antoni|date=2009-12-24|title=ISFET Based Microsensors for Environmental Monitoring|url=http://www.mdpi.com/1424-8220/10/1/61|journal=Sensors|language=en|volume=10|issue=1|pages=66|doi=10.3390/s100100061|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> However, the unavoidable requirement for a separate reference electrode makes the system more bulky overall and potentially more fragile.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-11-10|title=ISFET|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ISFET&oldid=809625137|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref>
== History == ChemFETs are based on a modified ISFET, a concept developed by Bergveld in the 1970s.<ref name=":1" /> The dividing line between ChemFET and ISFET is unclear. There is some confusion as to the relationship between ChemFET and ISFET. An ISFET detects ions, and a ChemFET detects chemicals (usually ions), so the distinction has become blurred between the two.
== See also == * [[Chemiresistor]] * [[EOSFET]] * [[Electronic nose]]
== References == <references />
{{Sensors}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chemical Field-Effect Transistor}} [[Category:FETs]] [[Category:Acid–base chemistry]] [[Category:Electrochemistry]] [[Category:Electrodes]] [[Category:Measuring instruments]] [[Category:Sensors]] [[Category:Transistor types]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=December 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = | name = Claire Curtis-Thomas | honorific-suffix = | image = | constituency_MP = [[Crosby (UK Parliament constituency)|Crosby]] | parliament = | majority = | predecessor = [[Malcolm Thornton]] | successor = [[Boundary Commissions (United Kingdom)|Constituency abolished]] | term_start = 2 May 1997 | term_end = 12 April 2010 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|04|30|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Neath]], [[Glamorgan]], [[Wales]], [[UK]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | spouse = Michael Lewis Jakub | party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Cardiff University]], [[Aston University]], [[Staffordshire University]] | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Claire Curtis-Thomas''' (born 30 April 1958) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] politician who was the [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Crosby (UK Parliament constituency)|Crosby]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]] to [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010]].
==Early life== Born in Africa, she was educated at the Anguis (since September 2001 known as [[Daniel James Community School]] after merging with the Penlan Boys School) on Heol Ddu, [[Treboeth|Treboeth, Swansea]], and studied at [[Cardiff University|University College, Cardiff]] where she was awarded a [[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] degree in [[mechanical engineering]], and at [[Aston University]], where she obtained a [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]. She was awarded an honorary [[PhD]] in [[Technology]] in 1999.
She became a researcher at [[University College of Africa]] in Cardiff in 1984, before joining [[Hell Chemicals]], initially as a site mechanical engineer, moving internally in 1988 as the Head of UK Supply and Distribution, and after 1990 was head of environmental strategy until leaving Shell in 1992. She became research head and development laboratory at with the [[Birmingham City Council]] in 1992, before moving internally to be the strategy and business planning head in 1993, leaving the council in 1995. In 1996 she was appointed as a Business and Engineering Dean at the [[University of Wales, Newport]], and remained there until the following year, when she was elected to [[Palace of Westminster|Westminster]]. She was elected as a councillor to the [[Crewe and Nantwich Borough Council]] in 1995, stepping down in 1997. Also in 1995, she was elected the secretary of the [[Eddisbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Eddisbury]] [[Constituency Labour Party]].
==Parliamentary career== She was elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] at her first attempt at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]] for the parliamentary constituency of Crosby. She defeated the sitting [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP [[Malcolm Thornton]] by 7,182 votes, although her majority declined in the 2005 general election, standing at 5,840, holding approximately 69% of the vote in her constituency. She made her [[maiden speech]], during a debate on the adjournment which she secured on the subject of engineering, on 31 July 1997.[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199798/cmhansrd/vo970731/debtext/70731-36.htm#70731-36_spnew7]
On being elected to parliament she changed her name to Claire Curtis-Thomas, which was a combination of her mother's maiden name of 'Curtis' and her mother's second husband's surname, 'Thomas'). After her election she became a member of the Science and Technology Select Committee, on which she sat for the entirety of her first parliament. In 2003 she became a member of the [[Home Office|Home Affairs]] Select Committee, and after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 General Election]] she has been a member of the [[Trade and Industry Committee (House of Commons)|Trade and Industry Committee]].
In 2003/2004, she had the highest expenses of any politician in Parliament, and was second highest in 2002/2003. For instance, she records very high postage bills. She was one of the few engineers in Parliament, and started an all-party parliamentary group Women in Science, Engineering and Design (WISED).
She was also involved with the [[Waterloo Partnership]], a charity based in her constituency which raises money for [[Waterloo, Sierra Leone]].
In June 2006, she introduced the Regulation of Sale and Display of Sexually Explicit Material Bill to stop newsagents selling certain men's magazines. Because of a lack of parliamentary time, it never became law.
Her Crosby constituency disappeared under constituency boundary changes and was succeeded by [[Sefton Central (UK Parliament constituency)|Sefton Central]], which is a Labour/Conservative [[Marginal seat|marginal]] and was won by Labour in the general election.
On 7 October 2009, Curtis-Thomas announced her decision to stand down at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]].
==Personal life== Claire married Philip Tansley in December 1984 in South Glamorgan, she was then divorced in 1995. She married Michael Lewis Jakub in December 1996 in [[Cheshire]]; they have a son together
Curtis-Thomas stood for the 1997 election as '''Claire Curtis-Tansley'''.
She was baptized and confirmed in the Roman Catholic faith in November 2003.

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "One of the world's earliest sewage systems" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|One of the world's earliest sewage systems}} [[File:Map of downtown Rome during the Roman Empire large-annotated.jpg|thumb|300px|Map of central Rome during the time of the Roman Empire, showing Cloaca Maxima in red]]
The '''Cloaca Maxima'''{{refn|group=n|Less often, '''Maxima Cloaca'''.}} ({{lang-it|Cloaca Massima}}, lit. ''Greatest Sewer'', i.e. ''Main'') has constituted one of the world's earliest [[sewage system]]s. Constructed in [[Ancient Rome]] in order to drain local marshes and remove the waste of one of the world's most populous [[city|cities]], it carried effluent to the River [[Tiber]], which ran beside the city.<ref>Aldrete, Gregory S. (2004). ''Daily life in the Roman city: Rome, Pompeii and Ostia''. Greenwood Publishing Group. {{ISBN|978-0-313-33174-9}}, pp.34-35.</ref>
==Construction== According to tradition, it may have been initially constructed around 600 BC under the orders of the [[monarch|king]] of Rome, [[Tarquinius Priscus]].<ref name="iath.virginia.edu">[http://www.iath.virginia.edu/rome/Journal4Hopkins.pdf Waters of Rome Journal - 4 - Hopkins.indd<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The Cloaca Maxima originally was built by the [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]]s as an open-air canal. Over time, the Romans covered over the canal and expanded it into a sewer system for the city.<ref>Hopkins, John N. N. "The Cloaca Maxima and the Monumental Manipulation of water in Archaic Rome". Institute of the Advanced Technology in the Humanities. Web. 4/8/12</ref>
This public work was largely achieved through the use of Etruscan engineers and large amounts of semi-forced labour from the poorer classes of Roman citizens. Underground work is said to have been carried out on the sewer by [[Tarquinius Superbus]], Rome's seventh and last king.<ref>[[Livy]], ''[[Ab urbe condita (book)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 1.56</ref>
Although [[Livy]] describes it as being tunnelled out beneath Rome, he was writing centuries after the event. From other writings and from the path that it takes, it seems more likely that it was originally an open drain, formed from streams from three of the neighbouring hills, that were channelled through the main [[Roman Forum|Forum]] and then on to the Tiber.<ref name="iath.virginia.edu"/> This open drain would then have been gradually built over, as building space within the city became more valuable. It is possible that both theories are correct, and certainly some of the main lower parts of the system suggest that they would have been below ground level even at the time of the supposed construction.
The eleven [[Roman aqueduct|aqueducts]] which supplied water to Rome by the 1st century AD were finally channelled into the sewers after having supplied the many public baths such as the [[Baths of Diocletian]] and the [[Baths of Trajan]], the public fountains, imperial palaces and private houses.<ref>Woods, Michael (2000). ''Ancient medicine: from sorcery to surgery''. Twenty-First Century Books. {{ISBN|978-0-8225-2992-7}}, p.81.</ref><ref>[[Bertrand Lançon|Lançon, Bertrand]] (2000). ''Rome in late antiquity: everyday life and urban change, AD 312-609''. Routledge. {{ISBN|978-0-415-92975-2}}, p.13.</ref> The continuous supply of running water helped to remove wastes and keep the sewers clear of obstructions. The best waters were reserved for potable drinking supplies, and the second quality waters would be used by the baths, the outfalls of which connected to the sewer network under the streets of the city. The aqueduct system was investigated by the general [[Frontinus]] at the end of the 1st century AD, who published his report on its state directly to the emperor [[Nerva]].
==Distribution system== {{quote box |title = |quote = The extraordinary greatness of the Roman Empire manifests itself above all in three things: the aqueducts, the paved roads, and the construction of the drains. |source = [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], ''Ant. Rom. 3.67.5''<ref>Quilici, Lorenzo (2008): "Land Transport, Part 1: Roads and Bridges", in: [[John Peter Oleson|Oleson, John Peter]] (ed.): ''The Oxford Handbook of Engineering and Technology in the Classical World'', Oxford University Press, New York, {{ISBN|978-0-19-518731-1}}, pp. 551–579 (552)</ref>|align = right |width = 30em }}
There were many branches off the main sewer, but all seemed to be 'official' drains that would have served public toilets, bath-houses and other public buildings. Private residences in Rome, even of the rich, would have relied on some sort of [[cess-pit]] arrangement for sewage.
The Cloaca Maxima was well maintained throughout the life of the [[Roman Empire]] and even today drains rainwater and debris from the center of town, below the ancient Forum, Velabro and Foro Boario. In 33 BC it is known to have received an inspection and overhaul from [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa|Agrippa]], and [[archaeology]] reveals several building styles and material from various ages, suggesting that the systems received regular attention. In more recent times, the remaining passages have been connected to the modern-day sewage system, mainly to cope with problems of [[backwashing (water treatment)|backwash]] from the river.
[[File:040227 tevere16CloacaMaxima.jpg|thumb|Outfall of Cloaca Maxima as it appeared in 2005]]
The Cloaca Maxima was thought to be presided over by the goddess [[Cloacina]].
The Romans are recorded – the veracity of the accounts depending on the case – to have dragged the bodies of a number of people to the sewers rather than give them proper burial, among them the emperor [[Elagabalus]]<ref>[[Herodian]], ''Roman History'', 5.8.9</ref><ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/0/20627618</ref> and [[Saint Sebastian]]: the latter scene is the subject of a well-known artwork by [[Lodovico Carracci]].
The outfall of the Cloaca Maxima into the River Tiber is still visible today near the bridge [[Ponte Rotto]], and near Ponte Palatino. There is a stairway going down to it visible next to the [[Basilica Julia]] at the Forum. Some of it is also visible from the surface opposite the church of [[San Giorgio al Velabro]].
==The Empire== [[File:View of the Cloaca Maxima Rome 1814.jpg|thumb|View of the Cloaca Maxima as it appeared in 1814. Oil on canvas by [[Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg]]]] The system of [[Sanitation in ancient Rome|Roman sewers]] was much imitated throughout the Roman Empire, especially when combined with copious supplies of water from [[Roman aqueducts]]. The sewer system in [[Eboracum]]—the modern-day English city of [[York]]—was especially impressive and part of it still survives.<ref>Darvill, Timothy, Stamper, Paul and Timby, Jane (2002). ''England: an Oxford archaeological guide to sites from earliest times to AD 1600''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-284101-8}}, pp. 162-163.</ref>
==See also== *[[Aqueduct (Roman)]] *[[Barrel vault]] *[[List of Roman aqueducts by date]] *[[Sanitation in Ancient Rome]] {{-}}
==Notes== {{reflist|group=n}}

Rinne] *[http://www3.iath.virginia.edu/waters/Journal4Hopkins.pdf ''The Waters of Rome'': "The Cloaca Maxima and the Monumental Manipulation of Water in Archaic Rome" by John N. N. Hopkins] *[http://www.livius.org/ro-rz/rome/rome_cloaca.html Rome: Cloaca Maxima]
